item.title: Learn
item.description: Live as if you were to die tomorrow. Learn as if you were to live forever. —Mahatma Gandhi, Goodreads citation (did not find any authoritative source of this quote) This used to be my motto for a long time before college, cannot recall when this disappeared from my active conscience. Caught my eye when Prof. Adam Porter quoted this in the announcement email for week 7 of his Coursera class on Programming Mobile Applications for Android Handheld Systems.

item.title: 15 Commitments of Conscious Leadership
item.description: Read as ‘commitment’ and then a ‘counter-commitment’ for each point. I commit to taking full responsibility for the circumstances of my life, and my physical, emotional, mental and spiritual wellbeing. I commit to support others to take full responsibility for their lives. I commit to blaming others and myself for what is wrong in the world. I commit to being a victim, villain, or a hero and taking more or less than 100% responsibility.

item.title: UNIX is basically a simple operating system but...
item.description: UNIX is basically a simple operating system, but you have to be a genius to understand the simplicity. —Dennis Ritchie. Source: http://www.linfo.org/q_unix.html See also Ashik’s post about his death - http://aashiks.in/blog/?p=270

item.title: even if you wrote 100% of the code...
item.description: …even if you wrote 100% of the code, and even if you are the best programmer in the world and will never need any help with the project at all, the thing that really matters is the users of the code. The code itself is unimportant; the project is only as useful as people actually find it. —Linus Torvalds, on Software Development Management. Source: http://h30565.www3.hp.com/t5/Feature-Articles/Linus-Torvalds-s-Lessons-on-Software-Development-Management/ba-p/440

item.title: 7 Commandments of the Personal Computer Revolution
item.description: 7 Commandments of the Personal Computer Revolution: Access to Computers - and anything that might teach you something about the way the world works - should be unlimited and total. Always yield to the Hands-on Imperative. All information should be free. Mistrust authority - promote decentralization. Hackers should be judged by their hacking, not bogus criteria such as degrees, age, race,or position. You can create art and beauty on a computer.

item.title: The Hacker Attitude
item.description: The Hacker Attitude: The world is full of fascinating problems waiting to be solved. No problem should ever have to be solved twice. Boredom and drudgery are evil. Freedom is good. Attitude is no substitute for competence. —Eric Steven Raymond at How To Become A Hacker

item.title: I am free no matter what rules surround...
item.description: I am free, no matter what rules surround me. If I find them tolerable, I tolerate them; if I find them too obnoxious, I break them. I am free because I know that I alone am morally responsible for everything I do. —Robert A. Heinlein, “The Moon Is a Harsh Mistress”, 1966. Source: http://en.wikiquote.org/wiki/The_Moon_Is_a_Harsh_Mistress

item.title: This is the last lecture I am giving you...
item.description: This is the last lecture I am giving you. From next class on, I will only respond to your questions. This course has plenty of readings. If you don’t have questions, it is either because you have not done your reading, or you are too stupid to be in this course. —At the beginning of all his PhD courses in Cognitive Psychology at CMU, Herbert Simon used to address his audience this way.

item.title: Hacker
item.description: Any person who likes to explore details of a system and extend their functionality as opposed to most people who prefer to learn the bare minimum. —Aanjhan Ranganathan (@tuxmaniac) Source: http://www.tuxmaniac.com/work/presentations/keynote.pdf
